Award.AwardTitle: Salish Sea Research Center: Transforming STEM Education in Native Environmental Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Northwest Indian College (NWIC) students will investigate the productivity potential of traditional indigenous aquaculture using a growth increment laboratory to compare the growth rate of modern harvested clams such as Saxidomous gigantea, to clam shells from the archeological records. In addition, students will conduct research on in-situ intertidal ecosystems using underwater video systems, or will explore the impact of ocean acidification on culturally and economically significant organisms such as clams and crabs, using SeaFET pH sensors to better understand changes occurring in nearby oceanic ecosystems.

These projects describe some of the ways that traditional knowledge and cultural experience will be combined with place-based research to enrich the Native Environmental Science degree and increase the relevance of STEM programs and careers to tribal students. It has been widely shown that undergraduate research experiences increase the success of students through STEM academic programs and related careers. In addition to increasing the STEM course offerings at NWIC, this project will promote the development of indigenous scholars through the creation of a space and organizational structure for student researchers, as well as capacity-building in the form of equipment to promote student and staff research. This project will increase the American Indian involvement in STEM measured through an increased achievement of Bachelor of Science, and graduate persistence into STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Salish Sea Research Center (SSRC) was developed to increase the presence and influence of Native American leadership in the area of conservation, science, and natural resource management. This project was to integrate SSRC research into courses and involve Native students in active learning to support their pursuit of a Bachelor of Science in Native Environmental Sciences at Northwest Indian College (NWIC).  NWIC is the only tribal college to offer a bachelor degree in Native Environmental Science. Tribal colleges are unique in their service of minority students with specialized skill sets, and challenges, which, at mainstream universities, often equates to very low enrollment in STEM programs. The primary activity of this award was to engage Native Environmental Sciences students using STEM curriculum enhanced with traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) and place based-research to promote cohorts of Indigenous scholars and increase student success in STEM Programs.

This project increased the research capacity of the SSRC an NWIC through equipment purchases for laboratory and field research, and resources to conduct field work. This included new microscopy tools, clam-growth increment analysis instrumentation, fluorometers, and fume hoods for precision research related to the marine environment. In addition, the research capacity of the SSRC was increased through the hiring of two new researchers, the Associate Director of the SSRC, and the STEM Education Outreach Coordinator. 

This project also aimed to increase faculty-driven integration of learning communities in and outside of classrooms at Northwest Indian College and included integration of SSRC research in sixteen classes. It also facilitated research opportunities of students on the SSRC research vessel, provided guest lectures to classes by SSRC researchers, and trained a number of faculty and students in the Indigenous Evaluation Framework.

Lastly, this project facilitated a culture of supportive student cohorts, through the implementation of the Science Student Lounge, which was designed by students to give science (and any) students a place to work together and form cohorts. Students use this space for homework, scholarship, GRE-prep, AISES meetings, and for a space to relax, and decompress. Students that have matriculated to nearby STEM master of science programs at mainstream universities often participate in Science Student Lounge activities, as well as K-12 STEM outreach with the local tribal communities.

This project was designed to address the culture of research at NWIC. Often Native students feel conflicted about research, stating it was not something that they saw themselves doing. Many of our students appreciate the space to include and honor their culture in their research. The SSRC, through this project, is able to offer a place through the laboratories and research infrastructure for students to conduct state of the art research, and provide support to NWIC BSNES classes where science and culture can be integrated. This project provided research support for eight summer interns at Northwest Indian College, and participated in more than 30 community STEM outreach events. Each year of this project, a number of students, staff, and faculty presented their research at local, national, and international conferences, showcasing the students’ growth as Indigenous scholars, and the role that the SSRC plays as a center for Indigenous scholarship. Furthermore, this project made geosciences more relevant to Native Americans, and completed the major goal to increase diverse representation in STEM fields. By offering relevant research capacity for the students, there was the opportunity for Indigenous students to enhance their research resume and increase the likelihood that they will matriculate to STEM Masters programs, as well as opportunities for employment in higher paying STEM fields.
